name: Campaign
label: Campaign Builder
instructions: Use this form to expand an idea into a playable RPG campaign.

fields.instructions: What changes are happening in the world?

fields.instructions: Grim, exciting, zany, lyrical, tactical, dream-like, happy, sad, desparate, exuberent, etc. How will the players feel?

fields.label: Visual Style

fields.name: end

fields.name: driver
fields.label: Drivers
fields.instructions: These are pattens for writing playable adventures. Pick some and describe how they work in this case.

hints.label: Agents
hints.description: PCs work for someone who sends them on adventures. James Bond works for MI6. Rebels work for the Rebel Alliance. Brave knights work for their king. Indian Jones works for the archeology deprtment at Marshall College. PCs can be an elite team. Or they might work in an obscure corner of some vast bureaucracy. And the varieties of jobs are endless. Consider The X-Files, Men in Black, Stargate, Sanctuary, Outland, Judge Dee, Agents of Shield, Battlestar Galactica, all the Star Treks, The Avengers, Blade Runner, Mission Impossible, and Torchwood.

hints.label: Secret War
hints.description:
The secret part allows the setting to look like our everyday world. (Or the everyday medieval world, etc.)

Secret War is often combined with Agents. But PCs can be pulled into a fight without formally signing up: Vampires vs Werewolves, Imortals vs Imortals, etc. Characters can be part of one side by birth, or sucked in when they learn the secret.

hints.label: Freelancers
hints.description:
Paid freelancers include Ghostbusters(tm), private detectives, bodyguards, bounty hunters, assassins, hackers, mercenaries, etc. PCs can be guns for hire, swords for hire, spells for hire, cyberdecks for hire, or have fast ships, or other vehicles, for hire.

The PCs are contacted by their customers, and paid to go on adventures.

hints.label: Privateers
hints.description:
Privateers were like pirates who operated during a war. They had permission from their side to attack and rob ships belonging to the other side.

In many fantasy RPGs, parties of humans, elves, are allowed to hunt down members of an "enemy" species and take their stuff.

Robin Hood was technially a bandit. But occupiers and opressors can exuse plenty of fun and profitable crime.

hints.label: Quest
hints.description: A journey to achieve a goal. The advantage is a single crystal clear goal. Quests may seek a magical treasure, a cure, or a personal fortune. The Lord of the Rings trilogy is a quest to destroy the ring. Battlestar Galactica is a quest for the legendary lost colony and a new home.

hints.label: Survival
hints.description:
PCs may be lost or marooned away from their own kind, trying to stay alive and find a way home. Castaways can be transported by fantastic means and can find themselves in very strange places. Examples: John Carter of Mars Lost in Space, and Farscape. A large group of castaways might turn into a colony. And exiles are deliberate castaways.

Or PCs might man a lonely outpost in a dangerous land, or simply try to stay a live in a deadly, futuristic urban wasteland. PCs might be hated, hunted, or tracked by a relentless foe. Survival might also depend on meeting a special need, such as a vampire's need for blood.

Survivors explore their environment, fight off attackers, and seek vital resources. They meet new friends and allies, and new enemies.

hints.label: Personal Mission
hints.description:
Or "personal quest". The PCs are doing something because they just really want to do it, or because they deeply believe it should be done.

They are driven to become the worlds greatest swordsman, to advance science, prove the Hollow Earth is real, or bring back Atlanntis. A PC's personal mission might also be an extended hunt or mystery.

A PC with a personal quest and a personal fortune can employ like-minded PCs in Jobs With Missions.

hints.label: Escape
hints.description: A kind of Quest. A desperate journey to Anywhere Else. Powerful, but best for short campaigns.

hints.label: Merchants
hints.description: business isn't always boring. Think of the early spice traders in Earth’s Age of Exploration, the caravans along the Silk Road, or maybe the fur traders of the American frontier.

hints.label: Keys Quest
hints.description:
A classic… The Great Magic Thing was divided into parts. The parts were scattered and hidden in dangerous places. And the PCs have a reason to find them.

Like all quests, it has a final end. But it has a bunch of intermediate ends, too. Twelve parts automatically gives you twelve adventures. Stretch it to a few adventures per part and you can get a whole year of play.

It’s over-used. But it’s over-used because it works.

hints.label: Wandering Heros
hints.description:
PCs have explicitly signed up to fight evil and help those in need. Examples: Knights of the Round Table, Dr. Who, The A-Team.

This is a popular classic. But make sure the players explicitly agree to it, because it requires the PCs to do dangerous things without any other rational motivation.

hints.label: Hunted
hints.description: Being personally hunted, or belonging to a hunted group, is kind of a downer by itself. But it's a great addition to some other drivers. PCs can be motivated by a goal up ahead and a danger behind.

hints.label: Treasure Hunters
hints.description:
Treasure hunters is popular in fiction and a straightforward source of adventures.

However, treasure hunters who are after the Big Score either get tired of failing, or succeed and retire. So don't count on treasure hunting alone for a long campaign.

hints.label: Assault
hints.description: Attack a place to achieve a goal.

fields.label: Character Classes
fields.instructions: Types of people in this world, who they are, and what they do. The rules don't have to be class based. Classes are just an awesome way to tell players about a world.

fields.label: Players' Introduction
fields.instructions: Tell the players about the world

fields.label: PC Creations Notes

fields.name: first_adventure
fields.label: First Adventures
